article.title: Oligodendrocyte Progenitors Display Enhanced Proliferation and Autophagy after Space Flight
article.abstract: Intracranial hypertension (ICP) and visual impairment intracranial pressure (VIIP) are some of the consequences of long-term space missions. Here we examined the behavior of oligodendrocyte progenitors (OLPs) after space flight using time-lapse microscopy.

sections.introduction: It has been reported that microgravity induces intracranial hypertension (ICP) and visual impairment intracranial pressure (VIIP) in astronauts after long-duration space missions.
sections.methods: Two years prior to the space flight, we tested several cell lines to select the most suitable for the space flight in terms of survival and hardware material compatibility, adequate seeding cell number to ensure cells would have enough nutrients for the duration of the trip, and so on.
sections.results: Upon return from the space flight on board SpX-21, OLPs were recovered from the passive flying hardware, seeded onto glass bottom flaskets and placed in the time-lapse system to ascertain cell proliferation.
sections.discussion: Gravity, the force that impacts our development, daily lives, and metabolic processes, is an integral part of our life, physiology, and cognition.

experimental_factors.organism_raw: human induced pluripotent stem cells, hiPS

article.insights_summary: This study examined the behavior of oligodendrocyte progenitors (OLPs) after space flight using time-lapse microscopy. The results showed that OLPs proliferated more after space flight and exhibited enhanced autophagy.
